sp.p: Madam, madam, the fault is your's, I pitied Rivers's distress, and should have relieved it had not you....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p:
Lord, sir, what would you have had me do? I'm sure I made the best guess I could,
and would have given the man any thing in the world had I only known that he wanted nothing.

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Madam, madam, you have committed the fault—you must repair it. Go this moment to my sister's, entreat her to intercede for us with Mr. Rivers, and either bring home his pardon or never hope for mine. Exit,

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Yes, I must go. Slip-slop, my cloak!—Such a princely fortune lost!—I remember now to have heard of Mortimer's immense wealth; and perhaps at the very moment he pleaded for half-a-crown, his pockets were stuffed with pearls and diamonds; and I warrant his odious black scratch periwig had been papilloted with bank-notes!—Oh! I could go distracted. Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORMOND.
sp.p: MISS Mandeville's manners coarse, and her person disagreeable?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Upon my word I thought so; but I've been so long absent from the fashionable circles, that possibly she may be the general taste; I'm only certain that she's not at all to mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: And when you spoke of her return to India....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Oh! she could not endure the very mention of it. I was really afraid she'd have gone into hysterics.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Strange! But, however, I'll ascertain the fact to-morrow, and this mystery shall be explained.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: 'Till then let the matter rest.—And now, my dear Emily... [A knocking without.] Hey! what can be the meaning of that thundering rap?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Lady Clara Modish.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Lady Clara Devil! and I'd rather meet the latter. Which way is she coming up?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: This way. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Then I'll go down the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh! pray stay.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: No, no; I'm not yet cool enough to conceal from the woman how heartily I despise her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Yet perhaps her neglect of you...

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: I guess what you would say, my good Emily. A moment of ill humour, a dish of tea too strong, a bad run of luck last night, the indisposition of her lap-dog, or any other fine-lady-like affliction, might occasion her indifference to my distress—but that she could see the infant graces of your child without interest, that she could suffer without compassion an heart like yours to languish in poverty, betrays an insensibility which I never can forgive. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You must though, my dear sir, or your heart is composed of tougher materials than I imagine. Yes, yes, Rivers and my brother must be friends, and probably that brings Lady Clara hither.—So, here she comes!

div3.stage: Servant shews in Lady Clara, and exit.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Ormond, I've just hurried hither for one instant!—Why, they tell me you've been indisposed. You look charmingly, however: But, you cruel creature, why did not you let me know you were ill?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Knowing your exquisite sensibility, Lady Clara, surely it had been barbarous in me to torture your nerves by a recital of my sufferings.
Oh! fye, fye! when the delicate attentions of friendship can alleviate....I protest, Mrs. Ormond, you've got a mighty pretty house here.
Tolerable. Mr. Rivers insisted upon my removing hither immediately, and therefore things are not quite....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p:
Mr. Rivers! Dear, that puts me in mind—I want to talk to you about him. Do
you know, he put the drollest trick upon me this morning!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [archly.] So he did upon me; but you were too cunning for him: I, poor innocent, was completely the dupe of his feigned distresses; but upon you, he tells me, they made not the slightest impression.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! no more they did—Ha, ha, ha!— [Aside] Spiteful thing, how I hate her!—But, my dear Mrs. Ormond, you...you relieved him then....

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh! the relief in my power to afford him was very moderate; and in truth our exchange of presents bore no proportion to one another. I had nothing to bestow on him but a very trifle and a dish of tea, and he repaid me with notes of not less than a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Mercy on me! a thousand pounds for a dish of tea? How unlucky it was that I had just sent away the chocolateThis trait is borrowed from Mercier's "Habitant de la Guadaloupe."!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Then he has such plans for equipages, diamonds, and estates....It would quite fatigue you, Lady Clara, only to hear the list.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Oh! I shall faint presently! [aside.] —But I hope the dear beggar thinks this trick of his as entertaining as you and I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I am afraid he takes the affair a little more seriously.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: But surely, my dear creature, you can explain to him....

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Believe me, Lady Clara, however great may be my cause of complaint, my brother's interest will never cease to be mine; and
if my interference can possibly produce a reconciliation....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: You will use it? Let me die now if that isn't being extremely kind; but indeed I always said you had one of the best hearts in the world. And suppose now, to lose no time, you were to bring Mr. Rivers to my house tonight?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: To-night? Why really....my mourning....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Oh! as to your mourning, you know you'll be considered as at home; for, is not my house, is not every thing I possess, as much yours as my own?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You're too kind, Lady Clara; indeed you're too kind!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Not at all! oh dear, not at all! I shall expect you then, and pray bring Mr. Rivers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I'll do my best; but in truth I doubt my being able to prevail on him, unless you can make use of Falstaff's excuse, and protest solemnly that you knew him all the while: however, if he should not come, depend upon it's not being a fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Well now, that's a dear creature; and I hope to Heaven you may suceeed! Yet should your endeavours to appease Mr. Rivers prove fruitless, I shall console myself with the reflection that at least my dear sister enjoys those advantages of which, by imprudence, I have deprived myself.— [Aside] Oh! I could tear her eyes out! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I suspect Lady Clara leaves me not too well pleased with her visit.—So, here comes Mr. Rivers!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: So, Emily, your visitor is gone; and now let me know what brought her hither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Can you seriously ask that question?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Why I believe I could guess—your brother no doubt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Even so. Lady Clara's errand was to express her contrition for this morning's adventure with all possible humility, and request your presence at her house to-night for the express purpose of receiving her husband's apologies and her own.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye? Well! well! I'm glad to hear it—I'll go—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye; and so shall you.—I intend to take the liberty of tormenting her Ladyship—and she'll not be the worse for a little wholesome mortification—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Nay, that is a fact which I cannot take upon me to deny.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
And now for the scene of action; where you shall see crowds of coxcombs, and legions of coquettes at my coming, all "dissolve,
And like the baseless fabric of a vision
Leave not one fop behind."

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You've a secret then for killing insects, I presume?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: No, only for dispersing them, and my talisman consists in pronouncing that single cabalistical word "Distress;" away they go; for in fact, my dear Emily, a fashionable friend is an absolute bird of passage,—
sp.l: Which here, while Summer reigns, enjoys the day,
Wings the warm gale, and courts the kindly ray:
But soon as Winter lours, and storms arise,
To brighter scenes the airy wanderer flies,
Where breathe less boisterous winds, where smile less clouded skies.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: The writ was executed, you say?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Oui, my lor; et Le Colonel Beauchamp, be tres bien lock up chez cet honnête, Monsieur Touchit!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Good! but unluckily Beauchamp has friends, who wont leave him there long.—Now could I find some lasting means of revenging myself on the puppy....What say you, monsieur?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Mais voyons, my lor, voyons! Suppose—suppose you carry off Mademoiselle Mandeville?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: I carry her off?—Why should I take the trouble?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Mon dieu! you not see?—Beauchamp love mademoiselle à la folie; but ven all of von sudden she disappear, he vil swear, vil cry, vil go distract! and ven Mademoiselle Mandeville been two tree day wid your lorship, serviteur à la reputation de Mademoiselle Mandeville.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um! the idea would be tolerable if it were not that afterwards Beauchamp might take it into his head to cut my throat.—Now that I shouldn't like, because you know it would dirty my neckloth.

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Ma foi, mi lor, en verite! dat it voud! mais l'Italie, mi lor? vy you not enlever la petite....

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Right, right.—But then how to get hold of her, monsieur?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Oh c'est bien facile! I go vid a chair to Lady Clara's, and as mademoiselle go in, or as she come out, I vip her into de sedan, de chair-men vip her up, your lorship vip her away; et voila' qu'elle est prise, pardi!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um, could this be done quietly, and in a proper way....for a bustle always bores me, 'pon my soul!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: How, in close consultation, my Lord? Perhaps I intrude.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Oh! by no means; I've a little business indeed, which....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: A secret?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um! you might serve me in it, if it were not—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: My dear lord, too happy if—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: And you'll be silent?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: As a conceal'd author, whose comedy has just been damn'd. I give you my word! and now—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: You must know, then, I'm on the point of eloping with a certain young lady....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: You? Good heavens! how can you take so much trouble! and have you a chaise-and-four ready?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: No, but I shall order my sedan chair to be prepared immediately.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: A sedan? 'Faith that's new!—Well, you'll order your chair to Gretna Green, I hope?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p:
Oh! you mistake the business: the lady in question is in love with a fellow, who bores
me intolerably; and I carry off his mistress, merely for the sake of plaguing him.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Merely for the sake of plaguing him!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Nothing else, 'pon my soul! The idea's good, an't it?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Good? it's excellent!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Now the only difficulty is, how to entice her to the spot where my servants will be waiting for her; and if any friend—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Entice her!—then she's not appris'd of the honour intended her by your lordship?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Has'nt the most distant idea of it; and, in fact, hates me like the devil.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Zounds! my lord, but that makes the joke a great deal better!—And could you possibly doubt my assisting so honourable a design?—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, (but remember your promise of secrecy) the lady is no other than Miss Mandeville; and as you are Beauchamp's friend—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Pshaw! what does that signify?—Isn't he a commoner, an't you a peer? Isn't he poor, an't you rich? Isn't he an old friend, an't you a new acquaintance? And can you doubt which of the two I should prefer serving?—My dear lord, pray judge a little more of me by yourself!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: [aside.] A sensible fellow, 'pon my soul!—You'll undertake then to—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And think myself too happy in being of use to you, only let your chair and servants be ready—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p:
Oh! monsieur shall take care of that.—Friponeau, attend this gentleman, conduct Miss Mandeville hither, and when she arrives wake me. [Exit FRIPONEAU] Good evening, Walsingham.
'Pon my soul extremely obliged to you; am indeed....a....a....a....'pon my soul! Exit.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Go thy ways, thou prince of puppies! But 'tis well that this fellow has made me his confident, for the consequences of his scheme might have been very unpleasant to Zorayda; but now to mar it, and, if possible, get him into a scrape, of which at present he little dreams. The scoundrel!—but alas! there are but too many in the world, who, like him, would soon make themselves villains, if nature hadn't kindly prevented it by making them fools.

div3.head: SCENE III.—
div3.stage: Company cross the Stage. Servants pass with refreshments.
Enter Miss CHATTERALL and Mrs. BLAB-ALL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Nay, my soul, if this letter be authentic, Lady Clara must give up Miss Mandeville, or my acquaintance, I'll assure you!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Oh dear! My dear, as to that, I shall visit Lady Clara no more at any rate, unless indeed she gives a masquerade; and then you know nobody need know whether one visits her or not.—But accept a favour from her bare-faced!—Lord, my love, I blush at the very thought! Oh 'tis a sad family!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Shocking, my dear!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p:
True, my life; only conceive! Beauchamp in gaol, Mrs. Ormond intriguing with him, Miss Mandeville eloped, and Lady Clara giving entertainments when her husband's going
to be arrested, and her brother's at the point of death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Oh! fye, fye, fye! I protest I'm quite shocked.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Shocked, my dear? so am I, an't I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: But Lord Listless dying? I never heard of that before.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: No? Dear, I thought every body had heard that Lord Listless having discovered an intrigue between Beauchamp and Mrs. Ormond with whom he was himself on certain terms....You understand me, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Oh Lord! yes my dear to be sure I do; well, my love, and so—

sp.speaker: Miss. CHAT.
sp.p: Well, and so, my life, my Lord was so severe in his observations, that at length Beauchamp got into a terrible rage, rapped out three great oaths that he'd be the death of him, seized a blunderbuss (which happened to be upon the breakfast table) shot his lordship through the body, and the Colonel and his enamorata immediately made off for France, with the intention of offering their services to the triumvirate. How odd! an't it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Odd indeed!—But lord! my life, how unlucky it was that Mrs. Ormond should happen to have a blunderbuss lying on her breakfast table?

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Extremely unlucky indeed, my dear. But come let us in, and if Miss Mandeville shews her face to night, I shall tell Lady Clara what I think of her very plainly! for after all, my dear, to own a truth, the greatest advantage I ever could find in walking straight myself in the path of virtue, was the privilege of insulting those who step a little on one side. Come, my dear! Exeunt.

div3.stage: [As they go off, enter WALSINGHAM and FRIPONEAU.]

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Do you see her? There she goes!

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Vid de scarlet plume?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The same: wait at the great entrance till I entice her to the door, then convey her to your master with all speed. Exit Friponeau.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Miss Chatterall!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Mr. Walsingham, didn't you—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Hush! speak softly! My dear young lady, I've just discovered the most abominable design, the most atrocious plot!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Eh! what? against me?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Against you!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Oh! Goodness defend me!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And am come to caution you not to venture near the great entrance without sufficient protection.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Dear me! and why?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The infamous agents of a certain nobleman are waiting there for the express purpose of carrying you off.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Lord bless me!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And though I well know your virtue to be proof against either force or artifice—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Undoubtedly!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Yet, as this affair would make such a disturbance—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Terrible!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Would get into all the newspapers—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Odious!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And render you the subject of general animadversion.....

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Execrable!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The consequences would be, that either your friends would fight a duel on your account—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Or you quiet the business by a marriage with his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Charming—Monstrous I mean!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The best thing you can do, therefore, is to send for a guard—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: I'll do it instantly—

sp.speaker: WAL
sp.p: Return home under its protection—

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: With the utmost diligence—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And above all, take care not to approach the great entrance.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: I approach it!—Oh Mr. Walsingham! I'd rather die than advance a single step towards it: Good evening, and a thousand thanks!

div3.stage: [A pause, after which Miss Chatterall puts in her head, looks round cautiously, then hurries across the stage, and exit.]

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: So my plot has taken effect. Now if her friends can but persuade Lord Listless to repair her injuries by marriage, (and I know he has no great fondness for fighting,) the breed will be excellent, and I shall immediately put in my claim for a puppy!

div3.stage: Enter ZORAYDA (in an Evening Dress) as from the Assembly Room.

sp.speaker: WALS.
sp.p: What, Miss Mandeville, retiring so early!—How is this?—You seem agitated!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Walsingham!—I know not how—I dare not—but you are Colonel Beauchamp's friend.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: He has none more sincere.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: A dreadful report is circulating within—a quarrel this morning—a duel—I heard the story but imperfectly, but heard enough to alarm me for Beauchamp's safety. For pity's sake, sir, hasten to him—and should you find this report well founded—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: I will strain every nerve to prevent the consequences. But what antagonist—?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Lord Listless was named.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Lord Listless! Oh! to my certain knowledge he is otherwise engaged at present, and has too much respect for his own safety to endanger any other person's. However, I'll go immediately in search of Beauchamp.—So farewell, my dear young lady! make yourself easy, and depend on my care. Exit.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I cannot rejoin the unfeeling crowd within! I'll to my chamber, and if possible to rest. Ah! no—there is now no rest for me!—Repose never visits my eye-lids till they close wearied with weeping: The sounds which lull me to sleep are the groans of a forsaken father, and the spirit of dreams still repeats to me his parting curse! Oh that my next slumbers might be the slumbers of the grave! Oh that my eyes could for ever shut out light, since my heart is closed against peace for ever!

lg.l: COLD winter frowns, but soon again
Shall lovely spring appear:
The sun is set, but soon again
His glorious head shall rear:
Night veils the skies, but soon shall day
Once more illume the plain;
But never can a guilty heart
Be soothed to peace again.
Oh! sad is my soul!
All my nights are pass'd in tears!
I think upon my father's house,
And all that home endears;
Think, how that father lov'd me well,
But all his love was vain;
I broke his heart, and never shall
Mine own know peace again.

div3.head: SCENE IV.—
div3.stage: A magnificent Apartment at Modish's, illuminated.
MODISH, TRIFLE, Lady HUBBUB, Mrs. BLAB-ALL, &c. discovered—Card Tables, &c.—Ladies and Gentlemen playing at them.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Well I never heard any thing so strange! Poor Lady Clara, I'm sure I pity her excessively, though I can't but own that she deserves it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Richly, Lady Hubbub, richly, And, for my part, I shan't be sorry to see her pride have a fall; which must be the case shortly, for they say Mr. Rivers has positively refused to advance Modish a single guinea.

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Nay it's even whispered there are three executions in the house at this moment.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh, as for that, since I have known it, this house has never been without an execution in it for three days together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Very true, and therefore I wonder that Modish should have neglected to provide himself with a rotten borough; for he ought to have known, that as he couldn't pay his debts, he had but one alternative, and must certainly get into prison unless he got into parliament.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh! here's Lady Clara!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [as entering.] How d'ye do? Charmed to see you! Been here long? You there, Trifle!—Ah, Lady Hubbub.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh my dear Lady Clara!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Mr. Rivers—I'm so concerned for you!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: I could cry with vexation!

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: To lose such a fortune by a trick my dear creature, it grieves me to the heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: And I'm told you must part with your beautiful set of cream coloured ponies?—Lord! Lord! you've no idea how that distresses me!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Now let me die but you're both of you very kind; and it quite delights me that I'm able to relieve you from such excessive affliction. Whatever you may have heard to the contrary, Mr. Rivers and Modish are on the best terms possible, and I hope in a few minutes to have the pleasure of making him known to you. [Aside] Spiteful toads!

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p:
No really! Lord, I'm prodigious
glad to hear it! [Aside] I wish you were both at the bottom of the Thames!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Delighted, my dear Lady Clara! Quite delighted, I protest!— [Aside] Another birth-day suit to cut out mine, I'd lay my life on't.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA,
sp.p: [aside] —Well, of all earthly torments, the sympathy of one's friends is certainly the greatest.—Ha! Miss Chatterall!—Heavens! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Oh Lady Clara! Oh Lady Hubbub!—I shall faint, Lady Hubbub I shall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Faint! Why, what has alarmed you?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Aye, aye!—All things in order; tell your story first, and faint afterwards.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Oh! your brother, Lady Clara! your vile brother!—I can't speak for passion!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: What indeed? Why he has—he has— [bursting into tears] —he has carried me off in a sedan chair! So he has!—How monstrous! wasn't it?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Carried you off!—Mercy, why should he do that?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Aye, why indeed?—Oh! I don't believe a word on't.

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Not believe it?—Oh Gemini! but it's very true though; and what's more, sir, what's more, I'm almost morally certain you're one of his accomplices!

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: I?—Oh fye, Miss Chatterall, fye!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Oh! fye, fye, fye!

sp.speaker: Miss CHAT.
sp.p: Fye, indeed! Fye? Oh that ever I should live to be fyed!—Lady Clara, as I hope to be married, was carried by force to your brother's house this evening; and when he first handed me out of the sedan, to give the devil his due, I must say he was civil enough; but as soon as he saw that I was I, and nobody but myself, he yawned in my face, said I was a great bore, put me into the chair, bade the men box me up tight, and, without saying another syllable, sent me back again! How disagreeable, wasn't it?— [crying bitterly.] —Never, no surely never before was such an insult offered to virtue, delicacy, and the first cousin of an Irish Peer!—But I'll be revenged! I'll to my lawyer's, and have an action for burglary brought against him without delay; and if the law won't do me right, I warrant my Irish uncle Sir Blarney O'Blunderbuss will!—Oh he'll come to my assistance, good soul, at the first word; will insist on his Lordship's repairing by marriage the injury done my reputation; and when I once find myself his wife—oh what a miserable wretch I'll make him! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [laughing.] —But what can all this mean? Ha! Modish, I see Rivers advancing.

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: [aside.] I tremble to meet him; I feel how ungratefully I have treated him; and my only consolation is, that I felt it before I knew how much my ingratitude had cost me.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: So here he comes—Now, ladies—now, ladies, you shall see—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [to RIVERS] —Remember your promise—Gentleness!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Oh, never fear!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [to Mrs. Ormond]. And here you are at last? My dear creature, you've no notion how you've agitated me; I've expected you this half hour, and was almost afraid that some accident had happened—and Mr. Rivers too, I declare!—My dear sir, I can scarcely thank you for this visit for laughing when I think of the ridiculous affair of this morning: well I never was so quizzed in my life; but you must certainly have a world of humour!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [drily.] Um, aye, it was ridiculous enough; but yet the best part of the joke is still to come.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Is it? Dear, I'm prodigiously glad to hear it, for it has entertained me so, you have no idea—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Pardon me, I can conceive it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Impossible, quite impossible! And indeed I called at your house this evening for the sole purpose of saying how extremely—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: My house!—Mrs. Ormond's you mean. Your Ladyship forgets—I live at the Three Blue Posts in Little Britain.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! very true; and Modish must pay his respects to you at the Three Blue Posts, I suppose?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: May I expect so much condescension from Mr. Modish?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p:
Mr. Rivers, I will not aggravate my fault by attempting to excuse it; I am heartily ashamed of my behaviour this morning, and see it
myself in such offensive colours, that I cannot hope by any present submissions to obtain your pardon.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Give me your hand, sir; the best thing is certainly not to commit a fault, but the next best is to be sorry for it when committed.—And yet, when you reflect on Lady Clara's very flattering reception of me this morning, you cannot possibly found any expectations on my assistance, though, Heaven knows, at this very moment you stand wofully in need of it.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: At this moment?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Certainly; for in the first place there is an execution in the house.

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Good night, Modish. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: There goes one! [aside.] —Then, Modish, Squeez'em the usurer has taken out a writ against you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Your servant, Lady Clara.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [aside] There go two!—So that you will certainly go to prison to-morrow, unless you can borrow a considerable sum among your acquaintance—

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Call Lady Hubbub's servants, if you please, sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [aside.] There goes a third!—And can get two of your friends to stand bail for you.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Mr. Modish, we wish you a very good night! Exeunt.

div3.stage: Manent RIVERS, MODISH, Lady CLARA, and Mrs. ORMOND.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo! There goes the whole covey!

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Narrow-hearted rascals!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What, all gone!—Lord bless me!—What, all!—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Lady Clara, the coast is clear; and what otherwise could you expect? what else than—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Hush! hush! my dear sir! Surely they are already sufficiently mortified, and to punish them farther would be both cruel and unnecessary—Suffer me then to plead for my brother—and—

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Emily, you must plead in vain: Lady Clara's imprudence has been too gross, my ingratitude too culpable to—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: May be so, George; but you may as well confine your reproaches to your own breast, since your sister has already carried the point for you, and I have promised to discharge your debts.

sp.speaker: MOD. and Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Dear sir, in what manner—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Nay, no thanks, or, if you needs must pay them, offer them to Emily; they are her due, and I can tell you, George—

div3.stage: Enter JOHN, delivers a Letter to Mrs. ORMOND, and exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [after reading it.] Good Heavens!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Emily, what has alarmed you? You change colour!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Something has happened which—Might I request a few moments private conversation with you?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p:
Oh! pray consider yourself at
home, my dear—we leave you. [To Modish] Will you come, Love?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Come, my life?—To be sure I will.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [looking after them.] Fudge!—And now Emily, what dismal tale have you to relate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: One, my dear sir, which interests me nearly. Soon after your leaving me this morning, I owed my rescue from the grossest impertinence to an officer, who unluckily was indebted for a large sum to the coxcomb by whom I was insulted. This note informs me, that, in consequence of having afforded me his protection, he has been arrested, and is now confined at the suit of Lord Listless.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Confined? He shall not be so long. England needs such men, nor shall she be deprived of them, while I can help it.—What does your friend owe?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Not less than 3000l.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: A large sum! But no matter! Set your heart at rest, Emily; the debt shall be discharged.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: My dear sir!—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Psha! dear nonsense! And his name?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You will be surprised to hear, that my friend is no other than Colonel Beauchamp.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [starting.] Beauchamp!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Even he; and his conduct to me this morning must convince you, that, if he has faults, he is not without virtues—but I hasten with these good tidings to Miss Mandeville.—Oh Mr. Rivers! believe me I feel well, how trifling a gift is the wealth which you heap upon me, compared
to the advantages which my son will reap from your acquaintance; much from your precepts, but more from your example. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [solus.] My embarrassments increase every hour—Why, why must Beauchamp have faults to none but me?—What course shall I pursue?—Suppose—Yes! I'll discharge his debts under a feigned name, and, when he's at liberty, challenge him in my own; the first to reward his merits, the second to avenge my wrongs! It shall be so—and if I fall to-morrow—then may my poor Zorayda find Heaven more merciful than she found her father!—May God forgive her, but I never can! Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I.—
div3.stage: ZORAYDA discovered seated on a Sofa, and leaning her Head on Mrs. ORMOND's Shoulder. Lady CLARA is standing near her.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: NAY, sweet Zorayda, why this despair? Probably ere this, the cause of yoor distress has ceased, and Beauchamp is at liberty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Calm your spirits, dearest girl! Believe me this excess of grief is childish, when every thing bids you hope—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Hope!—Mine is fled for ever!—My father, madam, my father!—I planted his path with thorns; I should have strewn it with roses:—he warmed me in his bosom; the snake stung him to the heart:—he loved me; I abandoned him:—he cursed me, and I dare not hope!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh blush, Zorayda! when thus sinking beneath misfortune—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Not beneath misfortune; 'tis beneath the burthen of my faults I sink. Oh! well may innocence see the lightning flash without alarm; well may virtue lift her head undaunted above the billows.—But when with sufferings comes the consciousness of their being deserved, oh they are insupportable, and I faint beneath the weight of mine!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Dear, unhappy girl!—Would to
Heaven Rivers were returned!—Pray, Lady Clara, did Zorayda see him this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: No: I have since heard that by some unaccountable mistake he was conducted to Miss Chatterall instead of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Miss Chatterall? Oh! then the case is clear. Know then, my Zorayda— [Knocking without.]

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Hark! a carriage stops—It must be Mr. Rivers.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [starting from the sopha.] Oh! I fear!—I fear!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You grow pale; retire, my love, and compose yourself.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: But Beauchamp—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: As soon as I have learnt the result of Rivers's visit, I will hasten to let you know it.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: And delay not, pray delay not!—Oh father, father! could you know what I feel at this moment, you would own, that, great as my faults have been, they are equalled by my sufferings!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Poor Zorayda!—Perhaps Mr. Rivers's intercession may induce her father—

div3.stage: Re-enter ZORAYDA hastily through the Folding-Doors.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Save me, madam!—Oh save me! save me!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: What alarms you?—Save you from whom?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: My father! Oh my father! I saw him from the window by the flambeau's light!—Even now he entered the house.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA and Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: How! Your father!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [without.] Very well—I'll go up stairs.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Hark! hark! hark! 'Tis his voice, 'tis his voice!—Oh! where shall I hide me, whither fly to avoid his resentment?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I know not what—Yet surely—Fear nothings my love; all shall yet be well—leave it to me; compose your spirits—retire, and wait till I rejoin you—Lady Clara!—

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: I will take care of her—Come, dear Zorayda!—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I obey; but, oh how cruel is it to shudder at his approach, whose sight is dearer to me than my own, and banish myself from his presence, whose embrace I would die to obtain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Yes, I must try it; Rivers must have his daughter again.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: So that business is done—There, Emily, set your heart at rest; your champion is free.—But hey! the deuce! you seem if possible still more disturbed than when I left you!—I hope you've not met with more impertinent peers and generous protectors?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Not exactly; the cause of my present emotion rather concerns my former protector.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: What! Beauchamp again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: No, the business now regards Beauchamp's mistress; but I find you've made a terrible mistake.—The lady you saw here this evening was a woman of the very strictest virtue.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
Zounds! what a blunder! Why the poor
creature must have thought me mad, for I proposed packing her off to India without ceremony. But where then is the real Miss Mandeville? Does she not reside with Lady Clara?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: She does, and you may now, my dear sir, execute the plan which—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Nay, I've blundered in the outset of it so confoundedly, that I wish some other person—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: No one can undertake this business so properly as yourself.—I've persuaded her that your intercession with her father—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Mine? Why I don't know him even by sight!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: True—but your consequence—your Indian connections—In short, see her; talk to her; advise her:—Shew her the impropriety of continuing with Beauchamp, paint to her what her father must suffer at her absence, and comfort her with the hope of obtaining his pardon:—But be gentle with her, I intreat you; moderate your naturally impetuous temper; and beware not to heap fresh anguish on an heart, whose wounds are already deep—whose sufferings are already exquisite!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Poor Emily! She little thinks that the man from whose friendship she hopes so much, in a few hours will either be expiring himself, or a fugitive from England, stained with the blood of Beauchamp! My will, however, secures her in affluence, and after that—

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. ORMOND and ZORAYDA veiled, through the Folding-Doors.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: But see, she comes with her protegée—Ha! veiled, I see!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [aside to Zorayda.] Nay, dearest girl, why thus terrified? Doubt it not, all will turn out well.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aside to Mrs. Ormond.] Yes, yes! 'tis he!—How I tremble at his presence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM
sp.p: In vain have I endeavoured, my dear sir, to convince Miss Mandeville that she dreads, without reason, the severity of your strictures. I assure her that you will speak to her....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Most soothingly! most kindly! Even as a father would speak to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [eagerly.] Right! exactly right! Remember your promise—Speak to her as an indulgent father would to his daughter, his beloved and repentant daughter. I leave you with her. My dear girl....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [embracing her] Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [aside] Would it were over! Yet what should I dread? I know well the excellence of his nature; and hard indeed must that heart be which can listen unmoved to the pleading of such a penitent! Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [after a pause] I...I...presume, Miss Mandeville, you are aware how delicate a task Mrs. Ormond has imposed on me. [Zorayda bows.] So delicate, in truth, that no sentiment could induce my undertaking it less strong than gratitude for your generous intentions towards myself, and the interest which Emily's account of you at first inspired me with, and which your own appearance could not fail to increase.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aside] Oh that dear voice! Yet how terrible it sounds!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
I will not dwell upon the worth of public opinion, the blessings of self-satisfaction, the torments of present shame and of future remorse; I
know full well how light these considerations weigh against love when a young hand holds the balance. 'Twas your heart which led you astray; to your heart then will I make my appeal; and, if it be not marble, I shall not make my appeal in vain. Miss Mandeville, I will speak of your father—will explain how heavy is a father's curse—will paint how dreadful is a father's anguish!—Well can I describe that anguish! I have felt it, feel it still! I once had a daughter—!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aside] His voice falters!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: This daughter....Oh! how I loved her, words cannot say, thought cannot measure!—This daughter sacrificed me for a villain, fled from my paternal roof, and....her flight has broken my heart—her ingratitude has dug my grave!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aside] How I suffer!—Oh my God!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [recovering himself] Young Lady, my daughter's seducer was Beauchamp! He has deserted her; so, doubt it not, will he desert you. My execration is upon her! Oh! let not your father's fall upon you as heavy. Haste to him ere it be too late! Wait not till his resentment becomes rooted—till his resolve becomes immutable—'till he sheds such burning tears as I now shed—'till he suffers such bitter pangs as I now suffer—'till he curses as I now curse....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [throwing aside her veil, and sinking on her knees] Spare me! spare me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Zorayda!— [after a pause] Away!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Pardon! pardon!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Leave me, girl!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p:
While I have life, never again! Never; no, not even though you still frown on me! Nay, struggle not!—Father, I am a poor desperate distracted creature! Still shall my lips, till sealed by
death, cry to you for mercy—still will I thus clasp my father's hand, till he cuts off mine, or else forgives me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Zorayda! Girl!.....Hence, foolish tears!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I hope not for kindness, I sue but for pardon—I ask not to live happy in your love, I plead but to die soothed by your forgiveness.—Still loath my fault, frown on me still, dash me on the earth, trample me in the dust, kill me—but forgive me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Her voice—her tears—I can support them no longer.

div3.stage: [Breaks from her, and hastens to the door.]

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [wringing her hands in despair] Cruel! cruel! My God! my God!—Oh! were my mother but alive!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [starting.] Her mother!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Ah! he stops. She lives then! lives too in his heart!—Oh! plead thou for me, sainted spirit! plead thou too, in former sorrows my greatest comfort, in present sufferings my only hope!— [Taking a picture from her bosom] Look on it, my father! 'tis the portrait of your wife, of your adored Zorayda!—Look on these eyes—you have so often said they were like mine. Be moved by my voice—you have so often said it reminded you of my mother's!—'Tis she who thus sinks at your feet—'tis she who now cries to you, Pardon your erring, your repentant child!—Father, I stand on the brink of ruin: already the ground gives way beneath my feet—yet a moment, and I am lost!—Save me! Father, save me! If not for my sake, if not for your own, oh father, father! save me for my mother's sake!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [Looking alternately at the portrait and her.] Zorayda—Zorayda!—My child! my child!

div3.stage: Enter MODISH, Lady CLARA, and Mrs. ORMOND.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM
sp.p: He yields, and we triumph.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [recovering himself.] Yet mark me, Zorayda—Beauchamp....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Never must you meet again; to-morrow either sees him stained with my blood, or this hand must....

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: How! Beauchamp?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Astonishment!— [To Zorayda sternly] Follow me!

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Rivers; hear me for one moment.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Hear you? Amazing confidence!—What? hear you extenuate your crime? hear you say that....

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: That I am guilty, that misery ought to be my lot; but that, if my lot be misery, it must also be Zorayda's. On your affection for her I throw myself Great have been my faults, great have been Zorayda's injuries—yet, if suffered to repair them....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Repair them! and your wife....

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p:
Her death has been long reported; this letter, just received, ascertains the fact. My hand is free, and from the first moment I beheld her that hand was destined to your daughter. I feel
how little I deserve her—feel the whole weight of my offence, and loath myself for its commission:—but my punishment would be Zorayda's—but Zorayda's fate is interwoven with mine. Be this my plea, when thus I kneel before you, imploring permission to expiate my faults to your daughter and yourself by affection for my wife and unremitting attention to her father.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Nor imagine, sir, that your wealth influences this proposal. Continue still your dispositions in Mrs. Ormond's favour; my fortune is ample, it has long been destined to Beauchamp, and the day which makes him your son makes him my heir.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [hesitating.] I know not...I ought not...

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Dear sir, if my entreaties....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: If my advice....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [embracing him.] Dear, dear father!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Pardon! pardon!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: I am vanquished! Rise, rise my son, and receive from me Zorayda!

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: My love! my wife! Oh, teach me to thank your father for so invaluable a gift!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Edward to be yours, and with his approbation!....Dear, dear sir, is not all this a dream? Am I indeed again your Zorayda? Is your affection indeed mine again?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Your's it was ever; and surely, had I loved you less, I had been appeased more easily. Many a pang, my child, has your absence cost me; but the pleasure of this moment overpays them all. Sweet, oh! sweet are a father's tears shed on the bosom of a repentant child. Hear this, ye flinty-hearted—hear it, and pardon!—Yet how is this? when every other face wears a smile, why hangs a cloud on the brow of my Zorayda?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Ah, my father! 'tis a cloud which must never be removed; for, 'tis the gloom of self-reproach!—I have erred, and been forgiven; but am I therefore less culpable?—Your indulgence has been great; but is my fault therefore less enormous? Oh, no, no, no! The calm of innocence has for ever left me, the courage of conscious virtue must be mine no more! Still must the memory of errors past torment me, and embitter every future joy:—still must I blush to read scorn in the world's eye, suspicion in my husband's:—and still must feel this painful truth most keenly, that she who once deviates from the paths of virtue, though she may obtain the forgiveness of others, never can obtain her own!

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.stage: The Ghost of QUEEN ELIZABETH rises in a Flash of Fire.

lg.l: Stare not, fair dames, nor criticize my dress;
You see before you jolly old Queen Bess,
Who from the land of roasting, boiling, stewing,
Is come to see what you above are doing!
Below, where some slight peccadilloes sent me,
Long did a wish, a foolish wish torment me,
For some few days in Britain to revive,
And view that land once more, I lov'd so well alive:—
This wish so teas'd me, morn, night, noon, and eve,
That I resolv'd to ask old Pluto's leave;
And though I knew to gain the point was hard,
Boldly dispatch'd Lord Burleigh with this card.
"Queen Bess's comp'ts to Pluto—begs to say
"She hopes, this card will find him well to-day;
"And should her visit now convenient be,
"Means to drink sulphur with his majesty.
For in our lower realms the truth to utter,
Sulphur means tea, and brimstone bread and butter.
Well, he receiv'd me, and (my sulphur sipp'd,)
"Dear Sir," quoth I—"I'm nervous, sick, and hipp'd,
"Besides have frightful dreams, and truth to speak,
"Scarce eat a chicken's pinion in a week.
"Shock'd at my sickly plight and strange condition,
"I've ask'd advice of maint and maint physician;
"And having heard them with one voice declare,
"Nothing can cure me but a change of air,
"'Tis my design, for health and for diversion,
"To Albion's Isle to make a short excursion—
At this old Pluto look'd extremely glum,
First scratch'd his head, then frown'd, and bit his thumb;
At length the business sifted to the dregs,
Thus spoke the king with the flame-coloured legs:
"Go, Bess," he answer'd ('twas not o'er civil
To crop my name, but 'tis an ill-bred Divle!)
"Go, Bess," he answered; "you've my full permission
"To visit London on this one condition.
"To-night at Drury, (so the papers tell)
"Is play'd a Comédie that's toute nouvelle"—
"I to this piece your new existence tie,
"And, as it lives or dies, you live or die.
"Should the dread ordeal with success be pass'd,
"Your second life shall for the season last;
"But, should it fail, instant (I'd have you know it)
"Here you return, and with you....bring the poet."
I took his offer, pack'd up hoods and ruffs,
Strait bodice, farthingales, and little muffs;
And least old Dis should take his promise back,
Through yon trap-door reach'd Drury in a crack.
Now then I come before the Public's throne,
To plead the author's cause, and eke my own.
Think with what terrors must my bosom tremble,
Since that the piece is bad I can't dissemble:
Yet, weary with my journey, faint with fright;
Pray don't oblige me to set out to-night;
Rather with kind applause prolong my stay,
And for a few short nights support the play.
But, should my prayers prove vain, should the piece fail,
The plot thought dull,—the humour coarse and stale,
Bess out of sorts, and Poet out of feather,
Are damn'd alike, and jog down stairs together.
